the statutory agent, a partner, the president, or in the case of an LLC, a
managing individual must submit to and provide the results of a BCI background
check.
   (c)    A short-term rental applicant may submit an application for a new
short-term rental permit at any time to the Director. If the application is
approved by the License Section and a new short-term rental permit is issued,
the permit shall take effect on the date of issuance and shall expire one
calendar year from the date of issuance. If the permit is issued in conjunction
with and contingent upon an explicit and consensual term lease agreement, as
contemplated in Section
777.03(b)(4), the permit shall take effect on the date of issuance and shall
expire upon the last day of the applicant's leasehold term or at the end of one
calendar year from the date of issuance, whichever occurs first. Proof of a
lease agreement, as defined in Section
777.03(b)(4), indicating the leasehold term length, shall be required where
applicable.
   (d)   A short-term rental applicant may submit an application for a short-
term rental renewal permit prior to the permit expiration date. If approved,
the short-term rental renewal permit shall take effect upon the expiration of
the previous permit. The renewal permit shall expire one calendar year from the
effective date. If the permit is renewed in conjunction with and contingent
upon an explicit and consensual term lease agreement, as contemplated in
Section
777.03(b)(4), the renewal permit shall take effect upon the expiration of the
previous permit and shall expire upon the last day of the applicant's leasehold
term or at the end of one calendar year from the effective date, whichever
occurs first. Proof of a lease agreement, as defined in Section
777.03(b)(4), indicating the forthcoming leasehold term length, shall be
required where applicable.
   (e)   The applicant shall notify the License Section of any change in
information contained in the permit application within ten (10) calendar days
of the change on a form provided by the License Section.
   (f)   Any transfer in ownership of a dwelling shall void any short-term
rental permit held in that owner's name and in connection with the specific
dwelling's property address. Such aforementioned transfers of ownership shall
require submission of a new permit application in consideration of and for the
issuance of a new short-term rental permit.
   (g)   If approved as a short-term rental by the License Section, a dwelling
shall be assigned an individual permit number that the applicant shall list
with the dwelling short-term rental on any hosting platform. Only a valid
permit which has been assigned to the dwelling being offered, listed,
advertised, or marketed as a short-term rental shall be listed on a hosting
platform. Upon a valid permit's expiration, no person or entity shall offer,
list, advertise or market a dwelling in violation of Section
777.02(a)(2). Any person or entity found engaging in or to have engaged in
conduct in violation of Section
777.02(a)(2) with an expired permit is subject to the penalties as provided for
in Section
777.18.
   (h)   The License Section shall have the authority to deny a new or a
renewal permit if any of the information required under this Section is
reasonably determined to be insufficient.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.04  SHORT-TERM RENTAL HOST AND HOSTING PLATFORM REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   A valid permit shall be required for each dwelling approved as a
short-term rental.
   (b)   A short-term rental host shall be either an owner or a permanent
occupant.
   (c)   A short-term rental host shall provide written notice to a short-term
rental guest of any known, non-obvious, or concealed condition, whether human-
made or artificial, which may present a danger to the short-term rental guest,
and shall designate a local 24-hour emergency contact person for the short-term
rental.
   (d)   A short-term rental host must comply with Ohio R.C. 2933.52. Such
compliance shall also include known, non-obvious or concealed surveillance
equipment, including, but not limited to, digital video cameras/recorders/
monitors, streaming video security cameras, audio recorders/monitors, or any
other electronic means of secretly watching, listening, or recording. In the
event a short-term rental host utilizes an indoor and/or outdoor interception
device(s), or any specific or similar aforementioned device, the short-term
rental host shall notify the short-term rental guest. In the event the short-
term rental guest does not consent to the short-term rental host utilizing an
indoor interception device(s), or any specific or similar aforementioned
device, the short-term rental host shall immediately deactivate the indoor
interception device(s) and shall not intercept, listen, monitor, record, or
like thereof, any activity inside the short-term rental.
   (e)   A short-term rental host shall comply with the City of Portsmouth
short-term rental excise taxes as required by Chapter
183 of the Codified Ordinances.
      (1)    A rental for thirty (30) or more consecutive days by the same
person(s) are not subject to short-term rental regulations or short-term rental
excise taxes.
   (f)   No person or entity shall offer, list, advertise or market a dwelling
with five (5) guestrooms or less, located within the City of Portsmouth, on an
entity's website, for which such entity is compensated for facilitating or
providing for a mechanism for a transaction, to rent or reserve the dwelling,
in whole or in part, for less than thirty (30) days, to another person, without
registering, listing, or accompanying a valid permit number, issued in
accordance with this chapter and associated with the dwelling.
   (g)   No entity, via the entity's website, shall provide for or facilitate a
mechanism for a transaction between an owner or permanent occupant and another
person to rent or reserve, in whole or in part, a dwelling with five (5)
guestrooms or less, located within the City of Portsmouth, unless the owner or
permanent occupant has registered or otherwise provided to the entity a valid
permit number, issued in accordance with this chapter and associated with the
dwelling.
   (h)   Records required.
      (1)    A short-term rental host who engages in, conducts, or carries on a
short-term rental, and a hosting platform that provides for or facilitates a
booking service, shall maintain and provide, when requested, records
documenting the following information:
         A.   The short-term rental physical address;
         B.   The name of the person or entity who registered the short-term
rental on the hosting platform or who listed the short-term rental on the
hosting platform; and
         C.   For each short-term rental guest, the dates and duration of stay
in a short-term rental, the number of persons who were scheduled to stay each
night, and the daily rate charged for each short-term rental guest.
      (2)    A hosting platform and a short-term rental host shall retain
records for a period of at least four (4) years.
      (3)    In order to determine whether an applicant, short-term rental host
or hosting platform is in compliance with the requirements of this Chapter, the
Director may request that any records relevant to or of assistance in a
compliance investigation, be provided for inspection. If such request is
denied, the Director may seek an administrative search warrant from a court of
competent jurisdiction authorizing said inspection.
   (i)   Nothing in this section shall be construed as permitting any person or
entity to obtain a permit or offer, list, advertise, or market a short-term
rental, where prohibited by any other provision of law. (Ord. 2022-75. Passed
9-12-22.)
777.05   GROUNDS FOR DENIAL, REVOCATION, OR SUSPENSION.
   (a)   The Director shall deny any application for a new permit or renewal of
permit, or revoke or suspend a permit, if any of the following are shown to
have occurred during the time of application or at the short-term rental
address, or applicant's dwelling:
      (1)    The applicant makes a material misrepresentation of fact on the
application or submits fraudulent, counterfeit, or false documentation;
      (2)    Any applicant, owner, operator, manager, short-term rental host or
property manager is shown to have been convicted of the act of prostitution or
soliciting for prostitution, or an act that would constitute a violation of the
Ohio R.C. Chapters 2925 or 3719, on the premises of the short-term rental in
question, the applicant's dwelling, or any short-term rental, or dwelling in
which the applicant, owner, or short-term rental host has any interest in,
including, but not limited to, ownership, licensure, or management;
      (3)    Applicant's dwelling or the property on which the hotel/motel or
short-term rental is located is not in good standing with the City of
Portsmouth Income Tax Division or is delinquent on Scioto County Ohio Real
Estate Tax;
      (4)    The applicant or the short-term rental host is not in good
standing with the City of Portsmouth Income Tax Division.
   (b)   The Director may deny any application for a new permit, or renewal of
permit, revoke or suspend a permit, if any of the following are shown to have
occurred during the time of application or at the hotel/motel, short-term
rental, or applicant's dwelling:
      (1)    The applicant has been convicted of violating Section
777.02(a)(1) or Section
 777.02(a)(2).
      (2)    The short-term rental or applicant's dwelling has outstanding
orders from the Portsmouth Division of Fire that have not been corrected;
      (3)    A pattern of felony drug related activity;
      (4)    A pattern of prostitution related activity or evidence of human
trafficking;
      (5)    A pattern of gang related activity as defined in Ohio R.C.
2923.41;
      (6)    A documented history or pattern at the short-term rental or
applicant's dwelling of repeated offenses of violence as defined in Ohio R.C.
2901.01;
      (7)    The short-term rental host has a documented history of repeated
offenses of violence as defined in Ohio R.C. 2901.01;
      (8)    The short-term rental or applicant's dwelling has three (3) or
more calls for service during a consecutive twelve-(12) months where at least
one of the twelve (12) months occurs within the calendar year in which an
objection to the permit is lodged;
      (9)    The applicant, the owner, manager, short-term rental host, or
property manager has not made a good faith effort to correct violations of
Section
777.05 or Section
777.15, or has obstructed or interfered with correction of the violations;
      (10)    Any applicant, owner, manager, short-term rental host or property
manager is shown to have engaged in the act of prostitution or soliciting for
prostitution, or an act that would constitute a violation of the Ohio R.C.
Chapters 2925 or 3719, on the premises of the short-term rental in question,
the applicant's dwelling, or any short-term rental or dwelling in which the
applicant, owner or short-term rental host has any interest in, including, but
not limited to, ownership, licensure, or management.
      (11)    An owner, manager, or operator of the hotel/motel, a short-term
rental host, or a property manager, or applicant has hindered or prevented any
inspection of the hotel/motel, short-term rental, or applicant's dwelling as
authorized by Section
777.12;
      (12)    The short-term rental or applicant's dwelling has a history of
repeated conduct that endangers neighborhood safety or diminishes resident's
quality of life.
      (13)    Applicant's dwelling or the short-term rental has a call for
service in relation to an allegation of a criminal violation of the P.C.O. or
the Ohio R.C..
      (14)    Applicant or the short-term rental host has been found guilty of
maintaining a public nuisance.
      (15)    Applicant's dwelling or the short-term rental has been declared a
public nuisance.
      (16)    Applicant or the short-term rental host has not abated the public
nuisance or complied with a notice of violations.
   (c)   Evidence of conduct under divisions (a) and (b) of Section
777.05 need only be that of de facto violation of law, evidence of conviction
is not a prerequisite for denial unless specifically indicated.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.06 OBJECTION TO NEW OR RENEWAL, REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION OF SHORT-TERM
RENTAL PERMIT.
   (a)   At any time during the calendar year, the License Section shall submit
an objection to the Director with regards to a new permit application or a
renewal application if it is determined that any ground set forth in Section
777.05(a) is found or shown to have occurred and where at least one of the
grounds occurred within the previous twelve (12) months.
   (b)   At any time during the calendar year, the License Section may submit
an objection to the Director with regards to a new permit application or a
renewal application if it is determined that any ground set forth in Section
777.05(b) is found or shown to have occurred where at least one of the grounds
occurred within the previous twelve (12) months.
   (c)   At any time during the calendar year, the License Section shall revoke
and/or suspend a short-term rental permit if it is determined that any ground
set forth in division (a) of Section
 777.05 is found or shown to have occurred where at least one of the grounds
occurred after the permit's issue date but before the permit's expiration date.
Prior to any action of suspension or revocation under Section
 777.06(c), the License Section shall submit a Notice of Suspension or Notice
of Revocation to the Director.
   (d)   At any time during the calendar year, the License Section may revoke
and/or suspend a short-term rental permit if it is determined that any ground
set forth in division (b) of Section
777.05 is found or shown to have occurred where at least one of the grounds
occurred after the permit's issue date but before the permit's expiration date.
Prior to any action of suspension or revocation under Section
777.06(d), the License Section shall submit a Notice of Suspension or Notice of
Revocation to the Director.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.07 NOTICE OF DENIAL, REVOCATION, OR SUSPENSION OF SHORT-TERM RENTAL PERMIT.
   (a)   If the License Section denies a new or renewal permit under Section
777.03(h), the License Section shall provide a Notice of Denial to the
applicant which shall list any and all grounds for such denial. Such Notice of
Denial shall be provided no later than seven (7) calendar days from the date of
denial.
   (b)   If a permit is automatically revoked under Section
777.13(b), the License Section shall provide a Notice of Revocation to the
owner and the grounds for such revocation. The Notice of Revocation shall be
provided within seven (7) calendar days from the date of a name change or
notice to the License Section, whichever occurs earlier in date.
   (c)   If the License Section denies a new or renewal permit under divisions
(a) or (b) of Section
777.05, the License Section shall provide a Notice of Denial to the applicant
which shall list any and all grounds for such denial. Such Notice of Denial
shall be provided no later than seven (7) calendar days from the date of
denial.
   (d)   At a minimum of seven (7) calendar days prior to such action of
revocation or suspension under Section
777.06(c) or (d), the License Section shall provide a Notice of Revocation or a
Notice of Suspension to the short-term rental host. The Notice of Revocation or
Notice of Suspension shall list all grounds for which the permit is being
revoked or suspended.
   (e)   The Director shall make every reasonable effort to personally serve
the short-term rental host with any Notice of Revocation or Notice of
Suspension.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.08  EMERGENCY REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF SHORT-TERM RENTAL PERMIT.
   (a)   Whenever the Director determines that an emergency exists which
requires immediate action of a revocation or suspension of a short-term rental
permit to protect the public health and safety, the Director shall issue a
written order to the short-term rental owner, short-term rental host, and/or
permanent occupant, reciting the existence of such an emergency and requiring
such action as the Director deems necessary be taken to meet the emergency.
   (b)   Notwithstanding other provisions of this chapter, such order shall be
effective immediately and shall be complied with immediately.
   (c)   Additionally, the Director shall make every reasonable effort to
personally serve the short-term rental host with the written order.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.09 APPEAL PROCEDURE AND STAY ORDER.
   (a)   All persons aggrieved by an order of the Director or License Section
denying the issuance or renewal of a permit or revoking or suspending a permit
who wish to appeal such order, may appeal such order to the Board of Licensing
Appeals and shall do so pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter.
   (b)   All appeals shall be perfected in the following manner:
      (1)    The appellant must file a written notice of appeal to the License
Section on a form approved by the Board of Licensing Appeals within twenty (20)
calendar days after receipt of the order from which the appellant appeals.
      (2)    The appellant must deposit with the License Section a fee of
thirty dollars ($30.00), which sum shall be refunded to the appellant only if
the Board of Licensing Appeals renders a decision in appellant's favor.
Otherwise, the deposit shall be forfeited and placed into the general fund of
the City.
      (3)    Within five (5) days after receipt by the License Section of the
notice of appeal, the License Section shall cause a true copy of the notice of
appeal to be docketed with the chairperson of the Board of Licensing Appeals.
      (4)    Within twenty (20) days after receipt by the chairperson of the
notice of appeal or, if a stay order is issued pursuant to Section
505.07 of the Codified Ordinances, then within sixty (60) days from the date of
issuance of the stay order, the chairperson shall cause a meeting of the Board
of Licensing Appeals to be convened for the purpose of hearing the appeal.
      (5)    In the event an expedited appeal is required pursuant to an
emergency revocation or suspension cited under Section
777.08(a), the chairperson shall cause a meeting of the Board of Licensing
Appeals to be convened for the purpose of hearing the appeal to conform with
the time limits therein.
         A.   The burden is on the appellee to prove by clear and convincing
evidence that an emergency existed which required immediate action on the part
of the Director. Appellant has no burden to prove there was not an emergency.
   (c)   An appeal does not automatically operate as a stay of a revocation or
suspension order by the Director or the License Section. If an appellant
desires a stay of such order pending the outcome of the hearing, appellant must
first apply in writing to the chairperson setting forth reasons for the stay.
The chairperson may request the License Section to render, in writing, its
views regarding the stay request. Within five (5) days after the receipt by the
chairperson of the request for a stay, the chairperson shall render a decision
on the request. If the chairperson determines that undue hardship to the
appellant will result by not issuing a stay and no apparent harm will be caused
to the citizens of the City by issuing a stay, a stay order, not to exceed
sixty (60) days and pending the outcome of the hearing, will be granted.
   (d)   In addition to the general review standards for a stay described in
Section
777.09(c), an action to revoke or suspend a hotel/motel permit may be stayed
should the property owner/operator take specific steps to remediate problems
outlined in the notice of revocation or suspension that include, but are not
limited to, some of the following actions:
      (1)    Completion of approved safety and security training, and/or
training to identify criminal activity such as human trafficking
      (2)    24-hour presence of special duty uniformed police or qualified
security
      (3)    Installation of safety and security measures such as fencing,
lighting, public space surveillance, etc.
      (4)    Voluntary sharing of guest information with law enforcement
      (5)    Voluntary participation in right-of-entry programs with law
enforcement agencies
      (6)    Implementation of minimum age of twenty-one (21) for check-in for
lodging properties
      (7)    Requirement of use of valid credit card at check in
      (8)    And/or additional remediation actions as approved by the Director.
         (Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.10 HEARING PROCESS.
   (a)   All hearings shall proceed as in a trial of a civil action with the
License Section having the burden of going forward. The License Section shall
be limited to evidence relating to the reasons set forth in its order unless
the Board of Licensing Appeals determines that justice to the citizens of the
City requires other evidence to be admitted.
   (b)   In all hearings, the Board of Licensing Appeals shall not be strictly
bound by the rules of evidence.
   (c)   All testimony shall be given under oath, to be administered by an
officer authorized to administer oaths, and shall be recorded by a stenographer
at a cost to the License Section.
   (d)   All parties shall have the right to appear and be heard in person, or
by legal counsel, to present their case.
   (e)   All parties shall have the right to:
      (1)    Offer and examine witnesses and present evidence in support of
their case; and
      (2)    Cross-examine adverse witnesses and offer evidence to refute
evidence offered in opposition; and
      (3)    Proffer evidence into the record if its admission has been denied.
         (Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.11 JUDICIAL REVIEW.
   The appellant and the License Section may appeal from a decision of the
Board of Licensing Appeals by perfecting such as provided in Ohio R.C. Chapter
2506. The cost of acquiring a transcript for such appeal shall be borne by the
party seeking to appeal.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.12 AUTHORITY TO CONDUCT INSPECTIONS.
   (a)   Upon display of the proper credentials, sworn officers excluded, any
employee of the division of police, division of fire, department of building
and zoning services, or Portsmouth Public Health may be permitted to inspect
the hotel/motel premises, short-term rental, or applicant's dwelling to ensure
compliance with this Chapter.
   (b)   If the request for inspection described in division (a) of this
section is denied, any sworn officer or employee of the division of police,
division of fire, department of building and zoning services, code enforcement
division, or Portsmouth Public Health may seek an administrative search warrant
from a court of competent jurisdiction authorizing said inspection.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.13  TRANSFER OF SHORT-TERM RENTAL PERMIT NOT PERMITTED.
   (a)   No permit issued under this Chapter shall be transferable or
assignable to another person or entity.
   (b)   Any person or entity found to have transferred, assigned, or attempted
to transfer or assign, a valid permit to another person or entity shall be
subject to the penalty under Section
777.18(e). Such transfer or assignment shall cause the associated permit to be
automatically revoked. (Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.14 DISCRIMINATION PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No person or entity shall:
      (1)    Decline a potential transient guest, transient guest, potential
short-term rental guest, or short-term rental guest based on race, sex, sexual
orientation, gender identity or expression, color, religion, ancestry, national
origin, age, disability, familial status or military status;
      (2)    Impose any different terms or conditions based on race, sex,
sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, color, religion, ancestry,
national origin, age, disability, familial status or military status;
      (3)    Post any listing or make any statement that discourages or
indicates a preference for or against any potential transient guest, transient
guest, potential short-term rental guest, or short-term rental guest on account
of race, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, color,
religion, ancestry, national origin, age, disability, familial status or
military status.
         (Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.15 DISPLAY OF SHORT-TERM RENTAL PERMIT.
   (a)   The short-term rental host or property manager shall maintain and
display the valid permit at the short-term rental.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.16 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)   The Director may promulgate and enforce reasonable rules and
regulations to carry out the intent of this Chapter.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.17  SEVERABILITY.
   (a)   In the event any section or provision of this Chapter shall be
declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or
unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of this Chapter
as a whole or any part thereof other than the part so declared to be invalid or
unconstitutional.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.18 SHORT-TERM RENTAL PENALTY.
   (a)    Any person or entity who violates Section
777.04(f), shall be guilty of an unclassified misdemeanor and shall be fined
not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). An offender who has been
previously convicted of or pleaded guilty to a violation of Section
777.04(f) is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. Where a violation of
Section
777.04(f) occurs in multiple listings, each listing shall constitute a separate
offense. This is a strict liability offense.
   (b)   Any entity that violates Section
777.04(g), without first correcting or remedying the violation in a reasonable
and timely manner, shall be guilty of an unclassified misdemeanor and shall be
fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). An offender who has
been previously convicted of or pleaded guilty to a violation of Section
777.04(g) is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. Where a violation of
Section
777.04(g) occurs in multiple short-term rentals, each violation shall
constitute a separate offense.
   (c)   Any person or entity who violates Section
777.02(a)(2) shall be guilty of an unclassified misdemeanor and shall be fined
not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). An offender who has been
previously convicted of or pleaded guilty to a violation of Section
 777.02(a)(2) is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. In addition, all
gross revenue or compensation from a reservation(s) or rental(s) that is
obtained in violation of Section
777.02(a)(2) shall be remitted to the City of Portsmouth, subject to local and
state laws governing forfeiture. This is a strict liability offense.
   (d)   Any person or entity who violates Section
777.15(a) shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. This is a strict liability
offense.
   (e)   Any person or entity who violates Section
777.13(b) shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. This is a strict liability
offense.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
   
777.19 BOARD OF SHORT-TERM RENTALS APPEALS ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby created the Board of Short Term Rentals Appeals, located in
the Department of Engineering, which shall hear appeals from any person
allegedly aggrieved by any order of the Director in the enforcement of the
provisions of this Chapter.
   The Board shall serve without compensation and shall consist of the City
Manager, the Solicitor and the President of Council.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.20  RECORD OF PROCEEDINGS.
   The Board shall determine its own rules and proceedings. A detailed record
of all proceedings had by the Board will be kept on file in the Department of
Engineering, which record shall be open to public inspection at all times. Such
records shall be retained for at least three years before being destroyed.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.21 POWERS OF THE BOARD.
   The Board of Short Term Rentals Appeals shall have the power to hear and
decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision or determination of the
Director or other city official which involves an interpretation or application
of the provisions of this Chapter.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.22 TIME FOR APPEAL.
   Any person aggrieved by an order of the Director may, within ten days after
the issuance of such order, file an appeal with the Board. Such appeal shall be
in writing on such forms as the Board shall prescribe and shall set forth in
particularity the order or ruling appealed from and the ground on which the
appellant alleges it to be invalid.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)
777.23  HEARING.
   A quorum of the Board, which quorum shall consist of two members, shall hear
such appeal upon written notice by the department issuing the order, on a date
within thirty days after receipt of the appeal and at least two days' written
notice of the hearing shall be given to the appellant. After the hearing, the
Board shall sustain, modify or withdraw the order of the Director by majority
vote, depending upon its finding as to whether the provisions of this Chapter
have been complied with, and the appellant and the Director shall be notified
in writing of such findings.
   The proceedings at such hearings, including the findings and decisions of
the Board and the reasons therefor, shall be summarized and reduced to writing
and entered as a matter of public record in the office of the Engineer. Such
record shall also include a copy of every notice and order issued in connection
with the matter.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 9-12-22.)

901.01 CORNERSTONES AND BENCH MARKS; TAMPERING AND REMOVAL.
   No person shall in any manner remove, deface or destroy any limestone bench
mark, cornerstone or any monument whatsoever which has been placed or
established within the City for the purpose of establishing the true location
of streets, alleys, lots or lands, unless where such replacement or relocation
is authorized by the City Engineer.
901.02 BUILDING ALONG LINE OF STREET OR ALLEY.
   No person shall build or place, or cause to be built or placed, any house,
shop, fence or structure of any kind, designed to be on the line of any street
or alley, without first ascertaining from the City Engineer the true position
of such line. Any person offending against this provision shall, on
notification by the City Engineer, forthwith proceed to remove the obstruction.
If not removed within a reasonable time, the same, by order of Council, may be
removed by the Department of Engineering at the expense of the person owning or
occupying the premises. This remedy shall be in addition to any penalty imposed
upon the offender under Section
901.99.
901.03 PLANKS REQUIRED FOR HEAVY LOADS.
   No person shall move or cause to be moved any load or burden exceeding eight
tons in weight along or across any paved street, avenue or alley in the City
unless the roadway is first suitably laid with plank not less than three inches
thick and twenty inches wide, under the direction of the Department of
Engineering. In no instance shall such load be moved or hauled except on
rollers whose surface contact is at least fifteen inches.
901.04 DRAGGING HEAVY ARTICLES OVER STREETS.
   No person shall drag or pull over the public streets within the limits of
the City any saw logs, timber or heavy articles of any kind.
901.05 DUMPING HEAVY LOADS ON PAVED STREETS.
   No person shall dump or unload upon any paved street, in such a manner as to
cause a sudden jolt thereon, any bodies of wood, stone, iron or other solid
substance whose weight is sufficient to injure the pavements, without first
thoroughly protecting the roadway with a good and sufficient plank or platform.
All such substances, however unloaded, whenever possible shall be piled and
ricked in such a manner as to present a smooth surface to the pavement so that
the weight shall be distributed as much as possible, and when necessary to
prevent injury to the street such piling or ricking shall be made upon a
suitable plank.
901.06 OBSTRUCTING STREETS.
   No person shall obstruct any street by placing in the roadway of the street
any scales, poles, postboxes or any article of any description which may become
an obstruction, without having first obtained the consent of the City Manager
to do so, and all persons owning, controlling or having in charge any such
articles so located in any street shall, when notified by the City Manager,
remove the same forthwith.
(Ord. 2015-83. Passed 12-14-15.)
901.07 HOUSE NUMBERING; SYSTEM.
   For the purpose of numbering all the houses, dwellings, shops, warehouses,
manufactories, or other buildings used for business purposes, fronting any
street, public square, space or other public highways within the City, the
following system shall be observed:
   Those streets running east and west shall be numbered eastwardly from the
Scioto River as a base line, allowing twenty feet for each number as nearly as
practicable. The odd numbers shall be placed on the north side of the streets,
and the even numbers on the south side of the streets. The streets running
north and south shall be numbered northwardly from Mill Street as a base line
allowing twenty feet for each number as nearly as practicable. The odd numbers
shall be placed on the west side of the street and the even numbers on the east
side of the street.
   The numbering of the streets shall be as follows:
   (a)   Beginning at Mill Street with number one and north to the corporation
line, allowing 100 numbers in sequence to each square north of the same, and
north of its line projected to the east and west.
   (b)   Beginning at the mouth of the Scioto River with number one and east to
the corporation line allowing 100 numbers in sequence to each square east of
the same, and east of a line projected north from it.
901.08 HOUSE NUMBERING; SIZE AND DISPLAY OF FIGURES.
   The numbers shall be composed of figures not less than two inches in size
from top to bottom and shall be fastened in a conspicuous place on the front of
each building.
901.09 HOUSE NUMBERING; DUTIES OF CITY ENGINEER.
   It shall be the duty of the City Engineer to ascertain the spaces of all
street numbers and, upon application, to furnish each property holder, or his
agent, with the number of his house, shop, store or other building. For this
purpose he shall prepare and keep in his office a plan of each street as may be
necessary to carry out the provisions hereof. The City Engineer is hereby
authorized and directed to perfect all details and to make such rules and
regulations as to numbers as shall carry into effect the system of numbering
houses as indicated herein.
901.10 HOUSE NUMBERING; DUTY OF PROPERTY OWNER.
   It shall be the duty of each and every owner of houses, dwellings, stores,
warehouses, shops, manufactories or other buildings used for business purposes,
within the City, according to the plans specified herein, and under the
direction of the City Engineer, to number his or her houses, dwellings, shops,
stores, warehouses, manufactories or other buildings used for business
purposes.
901.11 LITTERING; RESPONSIBILITY OF CITY MANAGER.
   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to take such steps as he
may deem effective to prevent the casting and leaving upon the streets and
public places of the City, waste paper and any other litter, in violation of
the ordinances of the City. For the purpose of taking such action as he may
deem proper, he shall cause to be erected and maintained at convenient and
suitable places upon such streets, alleys and public places, suitable boxes for
the collection, casting and temporary deposit therein of such waste paper and
other similar articles of litter, as now are likely to be cast upon the
streets. He shall provide and arrange for the cleaning and keeping clean of
such boxes and the removal and disposition of such waste paper and litter.
(Ord. 2015-89. Passed 12-14-15.)
901.12 OBSTRUCTION OF STREETS AND SIDEWALKS; RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNERS AND
OCCUPANTS.
   It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of, or any person having the
care of, any building or lot abutting upon a street or sidewalk, to cause such
street or sidewalk to be clear and free for passage. No dirt, wood, coal,
ashes, rock, stone, mud or other obstruction shall be allowed to impede the
free and convenient use of such sidewalks and streets. However, the provisions
of this section shall not apply to persons who have secured permission to store
building materials during the repair or construction of buildings.
   No owner or occupant of, or any person having the care of, any building or
abutting lot, shall deposit or permit to be deposited, either through his own
physical actions or by his failure to take reasonable preventive measures, any
dirt, wood, coal, ashes, rock, stone, mud or other refuse from or over his
premises that becomes an obstruction in any sewer, receiving basin, watercourse
or other place from which it may be carried or washed into a City sewer.
(Ord. 1954-121. Passed 8-25-54.)
901.13 NOTICE TO REMOVE OBSTRUCTIONS; BARRICADES AND LIGHTS.
   Whenever any debris, stone, dirt or any other substance is deposited on the
street or sidewalk by reason of any slide, collapse, washing away or crumbling
of the owner's land or structures, the owner shall remove such debris, stone,
dirt or other substance within five days after written notification by the City
Manager, and shall barricade and light such obstruction in the street or
sidewalk until complete removal of such debris, stone, dirt or other substance
is effected.
(Ord. 2016-02. Passed 1-25-16.)
901.14 REMEDY OF CITY UPON DEFAULT.
   Upon default of the owner to remove debris, stone, dirt or other substance
deposited on the street or sidewalk from or over his land, the City, after the
five-day written notice as provided in Section
901.13, may cause such debris, stone, dirt or other substance to be removed.
The Director of Service shall keep an accurate account, sworn to by him, of the
expense of performing the work, and such expense shall be a lien on such
property, which, if not paid by the owner within ten days of billing, shall be
certified by the City Auditor to the County Auditor to be placed on the tax
duplicate, and shall be collected in the same manner as taxes are collected and
turned in to the City Treasury, as provided for in Ohio R.C. Chapter 727. This
remedy shall be in addition to any penalty imposed upon the offender under
Section
901.99.
(Ord. 1954-121. Passed 8-25-54.)
901.15 OBSTRUCTION OF GUTTERS.
   No person shall obstruct any gutter or drain, or permit the same to be done,
or to become foul in front of or around his premises. It shall be the duty of
every person to keep the gutter around the premises owned or occupied by him
clear and clean by throwing whatever may have been deposited therein into heaps
convenient for removal. After having been notified by the Department of
Engineering to clean the same, no person shall neglect to do so.
901.16 CELLAR OPENINGS AND VAULTS TO BE CLOSED AT NIGHT.
   No person owning or occupying any cellar or vault, the entrance of which may
open on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place within the City,
shall cause or allow such entrance to be kept or remain open at any time
between twilight in the evening and daylight in the morning, without at the
same time having a light at such entrance.
901.17 PROJECTIONS FROM BUILDINGS INTO PUBLIC WAYS.
   No person shall make, place or allow to be made or placed, in any street or
public place in the City, any doorstep, cellar doors, basement passages, or
railings around the same, extending more than four feet into such street or
public place, or place in the alleys any window or air passage for cellars
which extends more than two feet from the line of the alley and which is not
covered by iron grating with bars not more than one-half inch apart. Whoever
violates this section shall remove the cause of offense within a reasonable
time after being advised of its constituting a violation of this section.
901.18 BUILDING MATERIALS ON STREETS; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   All applications for the use of streets or other public spaces of the City
for the purpose of depositing building materials thereon shall be made to the
City Engineer describing the grounds and the desired periods of occupation.
Permits for the use of streets and other public places for the deposit of
building materials shall not be granted, in the first instance, for a longer
time than four months, but may be renewed from time to time at the discretion
of the City Engineer for not more than one month at any one time. The permit
shall not authorize the preparation in the streets or places belonging to the
City of materials which can be prepared elsewhere, nor does it authorize the
deposit of materials in or over the gutter so as to prevent a free passage of
water, nor to extend beyond the middle of the street. The permit shall specify
the grounds to be occupied which must be in front of the premises to be built
upon unless more space is absolutely necessary.
901.19 PORTICOS.
   No person shall attach any portico or covered way to any building so as to
extend into or over any of the streets, alleys or sidewalks.
901.20 VENDING ICE CREAM FROM VEHICLES.
   The selling or vending of any ice cream or frozen confection from any
vehicle upon the streets or sidewalks of the City, is hereby permitted in areas
zoned as residential excepting streets with a posted speed of thirty-five (35)
mph or higher.
(Ord. 2022-06. Passed 2-28-22.)
901.21 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall perform work on a residential or commercial property within
the City right-of-way, including a public street, sidewalk or alley, unless a
permit to perform such work has been issued by the Engineering Department.
Proposed work does not include routine property maintenance items such as,
cutting grass or weeds, trimming trees and shrubs, and removing snow and ice.
Proposed work within the right-of-way includes items such as:
   (a)   Replace deteriorating existing driveway and/or sidewalk.
   (b)   Construct new or relocated existing driveway or sidewalk.
   (c)   Repair downspout drains which discharge into roadway.
   (d)   New landscaping such as planting trees or shrubs.
   (e)   Replace deteriorating existing driveway culvert/bridge.
   The cost of a permit shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). No permit is to
be issued until this administrative permit fee is paid. The purpose of this
permit is to ensure uniform standards of restoration or new construction with
City right-of-way.
(Ord. 2021-63. Passed 9-27-21.)
901.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Part Nine - Streets, Utilities and
Public Services Code, where no other penalty is provided, is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree.
CHAPTER 903

CROSS REFERENCES

521.03
 
 
903.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person and no department of the City, other than the department in charge
of street repair and the duly accredited officers of such department, shall
make any openings in the surface or pavement of any street, alley, sidewalk or
public way of the City unless a permit to make such opening has been issued in
accordance with the regulations contained in this chapter. The cost of said
permit shall be one dollar ($1.00) per square yard of proposed street opening
(s). ($50.00) minimum fee). This fee is assessed to compensate for the loss of
integrity of street pavements resulting from cutting, excavating and patching
of the street. No permit is to be issued until this administrative/permit fee
is paid.
(Ord. 2021-64. Passed 9-27-21.)
903.02 APPLICATION AND ISSUANCE; SECURITY.
   Any person desiring to make any opening in any surface or pavement of any
street, alley, sidewalk or public way of the City shall file with the City
Engineer, on a blank provided therefor, an application for a permit, which
application shall state the name of the applicant, the name of the street, the
kind of pavement thereon, the purpose of the proposed opening and the exact
size and location of the proposed opening, when, in the opinion of the City
Engineer, such giving of such exact size and location is practicable. Before
any permit can be issued in response to this application, ample security must
be given to the City Auditor to insure the proper restoration and subsequent
maintenance for a period of two years of the street pavement disturbed. Such
security shall be furnished in one of the following ways:
   (a)   A cash deposit may be made with each application sufficient to cover
the cost of restoration; or
   (b)   A general deposit may be made, to be replenished from time to time,
and to constitute a running account against which permits may be issued.
However, no permit shall be issued when the net unencumbered balance in the
account becomes less than the estimated cost of the requisite restoration.
   In the case of City contracts involving the cutting of street pavements,
permits may be issued without a cash deposit, but in such cases sufficient
money to pay for the necessary street restoration shall be withheld from the
contract moneys owing to the contractor until such street restoration is
completed by the contractor to the satisfaction of the City Engineer, or until
such contractor has paid to the City the requisite amount for the street
restoration. The cost of restoring the street surface shall be determined
according to the rules prescribed by the City Engineer, and may be estimated at
a certain price per square foot for each kind of street pavement, or may be
estimated by the actual cost of labor and material necessary to restore the
pavement over the opening, plus a certain percentage for inspection and
maintenance.
   Upon filing of the above application and the presentation of the evidence
that sufficient security is on deposit to cover the estimated cost of restoring
the street as above specified, the City Engineer may issue a permit to make the
opening described in the application, such permit to state the name of the
applicant, the name of the street, the kind of pavement thereon, the purpose of
the proposed opening and the exact size and location of the proposed opening,
when, in the opinion of the City Engineer, the giving of such size and location
is practicable. Where, however, the nature of the proposed work is such as to
require a series of openings close together, and where, in the opinion of the
City Engineer, it is impossible or impracticable to determine in advance the
exact size and location of the proposed openings, a permit may be issued to
cover such series of openings for such length of street as may be deemed proper
by the City Engineer. In such case, however, should any opening be made of
greater size than can be repaved by the deposit on hand, and in case it is
found that such opening has exceeded this size, the City Engineer shall
immediately cause such work on such opening to cease until such deposit is
increased.
   When any City department or division requires the installation of
underground conduits or structures, it may obtain the necessary street opening
permits without any cash deposit. The department or division shall be charged,
however, for the necessary street restoration work, and the amount of the
charge shall be paid out of the appropriation for the respective department or
division. In such cases, the City Manager may, in his discretion direct the
performance of the street restoration work to be done by the Department of
Engineering without charging the department or division for whose purposes the
work is done.
   No cash deposit shall be required from the County of Scioto or the State of
Ohio for street opening permits. Where in any such case the work done inures
greatly to the benefit of the City, the street restoration may, with the
approval of the City Manager, be made at the cost of the City.
   (c)   Upon approval by the City Manager, a public utility company may
annually sign a letter of agreement which states that restoration will be
completed to the satisfaction of the City Engineering Department within the
time specified on the street opening permit and to insure the subsequent
maintenance of the street pavement disturbed for a period of two years.
      (Ord. 2016-43. Passed 6-27-16.)
903.03 OPENINGS BY PUBLIC UTILITY CORPORATIONS.
   Where a public utility corporation is authorized by special agreement with
the City to do its own restoration work in connection with the opening of
streets for maintenance and construction work, the required deposit shall be
sufficient to cover inspection costs. If, however, in any case the restoration
is to be made by the City, the deposit shall be increased accordingly. Any such
public utility corporation shall be permitted to maintain with the City Auditor
a general deposit account, to be replenished from time to time, against which
permits may be issued. No permit shall be issued when the net unencumbered
balance is less than the amount necessary to cover the estimated City costs for
inspection and restoration if the same should be required.
(Ord. 1954-46. Passed 4-14-54.)
903.04 STREET CONSTRUCTION, MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR FUND.
   All moneys received under the provisions of Section
903.03 as deposits shall be paid to the City Auditor and credited to a fund
known as the Street Construction, Maintenance and Repair Fund, and the cost of
restoring streets, alleys, sidewalks or public ways after such openings have
been made and the backfilling has been satisfactorily completed by the party
making the opening, shall be paid by the Auditor out of such Fund upon the
presentation of the proper voucher of payroll signed according to law.
(Ord. 2016-165. Passed 11-28-16.)
903.05 RESTORATION AND REPAVEMENT.
   Where openings have been or are to be made in a street, the City Engineer
shall provide for the restoration of the street pavement in one of the
following ways:
   (a)   The entire work of restoration, including both paving surface and
paving base, may be performed directly by the department in charge of street
repairs, after the permittee has completed the backfill.
   (b)   The paving surface may be installed by the department in charge of
street repair after the permittee has made the backfill and installed the
pavement base.
   (c)   The work may be done either completely as in subsection (a), or as to
paving surface only, as in subsection (b), by a City contractor hereunto duly
authorized by contract with the City.
   (d)   The entire work of restoration may be done by the permittee.
   In all cases the entire work shall be carried out under the direction and to
the satisfaction of the City Engineer, and in accordance with the rules,
regulations and specifications approved by the City Manager.
(Ord. 2016-166. Passed 11-28-16.)
903.06 AUTHORITY AND DUTIES OF CITY ENGINEER.
   The City Engineer is hereby authorized and directed to prepare and to keep
on hand suitable forms for applications to be made and for permits to be
granted under the provisions of this chapter, and to adopt and enforce suitable
rules and regulations for determining the estimated cost of the restoration of
any opening in any street, alley, sidewalk or public way, and for the
restoration, by the department in charge of street repair, of such openings,
and to employ such clerks, inspectors and other employees as may be deemed
necessary by the Director of Service to carry into effect the provisions of
this chapter.
(Ord. 1993-84. Passed 8-9-93.)
903.07 EMERGENCY OPENINGS.
   No annual, emergency or blanket permit for more than one opening shall be
granted by the City Engineer. However, in unforeseen emergencies, when the
necessities of the public require, public service corporations shall be allowed
to make such openings. In such cases, a regular permit shall be obtained by
such corporation as soon as possible after such opening is made.
903.08 LAYING OF SERVICE PIPES PRIOR TO PAVING.
   It shall be the duty of the Department of Engineering, and it is hereby
required of the Department, that whenever any street is being prepared for the
paving of the roadway of the same, the Department shall cause to be placed
thereunder, before the pavement is laid, service pipes both for water and for
gas for every lot on the street to be paved which has not already service pipes
for water or gas.
903.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
901.99 if no penalty is otherwise provided.)

901
 
 
905.01 OBSTRUCTIONS AND USE OF SIDEWALKS.
   No person shall place any barrels, casks, boxes, crates, castings, lumber or
any other article on or over any of the sidewalks of the City, or suspend the
same from any building, or place on the sidewalk any design, device or
signboard, extending more than four feet from the line of the street or more
than four feet six inches above the pavement of the sidewalk. Persons may use
the sidewalk for the purpose of conveying their property to and from their
premises, and no person owning property abutting thereon shall open or maintain
any areaway or cellar opening without having the same securely covered.
905.02 GATES.
   No owner of real property within the City or agent having control of such
property shall permit any gate or gates to be, or to remain, so constructed as
to enable the same to swing over or across any portion of the sidewalk in front
of such premises, unless such gate is hung with self-closing hinges or has
attached thereto, weights, springs or other devices so that the gate will swing
back from the sidewalk and not obstruct the same.
905.03 DIGGING VAULTS.
   All applications for digging vaults or areas under or in a sidewalk shall be
made to Council. Council may grant the same subject to whatever restrictions
and conditions it deems proper.
905.04 AWNINGS AND SIGNS.
   No owner or occupant of any house, store or other building shall erect or
construct or cause or permit to be erected or constructed or permit to remain
erected or constructed, any awning, signboard or other device, structure or
thing, in front of any such house, store or other building, on any street in
the City when such awning, signboard or other device, structure or thing is
less than eight feet, in the case of awnings, and nine feet, in the case of
signs, above the surface of the pavement of the sidewalk in front of such
store, house or other building. No wooden awning or other roof shall be
constructed over any of the sidewalks of the City. All awnings shall be of
canvas or other like material, so constructed as to be rolled or folded up to
the wall when not in use.
905.05 AUTHORITY OF DEPARTMENT OF ENGINEERING.
   In regard to the determination of points, lines, distances, dimensions and
grades, the owners or persons doing the work referred to in this chapter shall
be governed by the direction of the Department of Engineering, whose duty it
shall be to give all necessary instructions in relation thereto whenever the
same may be necessary in the prosecution of the work.
905.06 SIDEWALK REPAIR; RESPONSIBILITY OF ABUTTING OWNERS; REMEDY BY CITY.
   It shall be the duty of the owners of lots abutting on sidewalks in the City
to keep such sidewalks in good repair in front of their premises and to prevent
any unevenness in the surface grade of such sidewalks by any reason whatsoever.
However, should it be determined by the City Forester that the damage or
unevenness is caused by the City planting trees within the immediate area; the
City shall then make the repair at no expense to the abutting property owner.
   It shall be the duty of the Auditor, upon resolution by Council, to first
cause notice to be given to the owner of premises abutting upon such sidewalk
of any necessary repairs or improvements. If such owner shall not within thirty
days thereafter make the necessary repairs or improvements in such sidewalks,
the same shall be done by the City or its designated agent. The expense of such
necessary repairs or improvements shall be assessed upon the premises so
abutting and shall be certified by the proper City official to the County
Auditor, and such assessment shall act as a lien upon the property of such
owner and shall be collected as provided for in the case of special
assessments.
(Ord. 2005-87. Passed 11-28-05.)
905.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
901.99 if no penalty is otherwise provided.)
CHAPTER 907

907.01 CONSTRUCTION; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Before constructing, reconstructing, enlarging, altering or repairing any
parking area designed for or used by the public other than parking spaces
provided as an accessory use to property used and occupied exclusively for
single or two-family residential units, the owner, lessee or other person
desiring to so construct, reconstruct, enlarge, alter or repair such parking
area shall apply to the Building Officer for a permit therefor and shall
accompany such application by plans, specifications, profiles and drawings
sufficient for such Building Officer to determine whether or not the area after
completion of the work contemplated will meet the requirements of this chapter
and other applicable provisions of the ordinances and other legislation of the
City and the rules and regulations established and promulgated pursuant
thereto.
(Ord. 1966-88. Passed 7-14-66.)
907.02 MATERIALS.
   All parking areas contemplated by this chapter shall be constructed of
concrete, asphalt or other equivalent clean, hard surface material in
accordance with rules and regulations prescribed by the City Manager. However,
in industrial areas where heavy vehicles and machinery are required to or
customarily operate over such areas and the emission of dust from the parking
area is not objectionable to surrounding properties, the City Manager, upon
application, may authorize the use or continuance of use of stone or other
material in such parking areas.
(Ord. 2016-44. Passed 6-27-16.)
907.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
901.99 if no penalty is otherwise provided.)

CHAPTER 921
Sewers Generally

921.04   Disposition of waste waters.

921.01 INJURY TO SYSTEM.
   No person shall remove any embankment around any of the sewers, culverts or
drains, or cause to be broken or injured any part of the arches of the sewers,
culverts or drains, without permission of the City Engineer, or remove or
obstruct any of the inlets of the sewers, culverts or drains, or break, injure
or remove any portion of any catch basin, manhole cover or any part of any
sewer or appurtenances thereto, or obstruct, in any manner, the inlet or outlet
of any sewer drain. Whoever violates this section shall, in addition to the
penalty imposed under Section
901.99, be held liable for all damages to persons or property in consequence of
such act.
921.02 PERMITTING ADJOINING PROPERTY OWNERS TO TAP LATERAL SEWER.
   No person shall permit an adjoining property owner to tap his house
connections, connecting with the main sewer, unless permission is first
obtained from the City Engineer.
921.03 OBSTRUCTING SEWERS AND DRAINS.
   No article of obstruction of any kind whatever of a tougher or harder
texture than newspaper or toilet paper shall be placed, thrown or deposited in
any catch basin, sewer, or drain in the City. (Ord. 2016-152. Passed 11-14-16.)
921.04 DISPOSITION OF WASTE WATERS.
   The waste water that shall be discharged into the sanitary sewer, and in no
case into the storm water sewers, shall consist of:
   (a)   Waste water from sinks.
   (b)   Waste water from toilets.
   (c)   Waste water from bathtubs.
   (d)   Waste water from urinals.
   (e)   Waste water from slop hoppers and garbage disposals.
   (f)   Waste water from laundries.
   (g)   Basement floor drainage.
   (h)   Elevator waste water, which may only be permitted to discharge into
the sanitary sewer under the direction of, or by permission of the Director of
Public Utilities - Wastewater.
   Industrial wastes shall not be discharged into a storm sewer, but may be
discharged into a sanitary sewer if the waste is of such a character as not to
be detrimental to the sewers, or the sewage treatment plant. Where such wastes
are detrimental to the sewers or the sewage treatment plant they shall be
otherwise disposed of in a satisfactory manner, or so improved in character as
not to be detrimental to the sewer system or the sewage treatment plant.
   Surface water, rain water from roofs, subsoil drainage, clean water from
condensers and any other clean and unobjectionable waste water, shall be
discharged into storm sewers, and in no case into sanitary sewers.
(Ord. 2016-153. Passed 11-14-16.)
921.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided
by Section
901.99, and any person who makes an illegal connection to a sewer shall, when
ordered by the City Engineer, remove such connection within thirty days of the
date of such notice. Each day the illegal connection continues beyond the
thirtieth day after notice shall be considered a new offense.
(Ord. 1963-134. Passed 10-24-63.)
CHAPTER 923
Storm Sewers
923.01   Tapping; discretion of City Engineer.
923.02   Tapping fee.
923.03   Drainage.
 
CROSS REFERENCES

921.04
 
 
923.01 TAPPING; DISCRETION OF CITY ENGINEER.
   Any person desiring to tap into a storm sewer in the City shall make
application in writing to the City Engineer for permission to do so, specifying
the property for which such tapping is desired and the point at which such
tapping is to be made, with a description of the property to be drained. The
City Engineer shall thereupon examine into the advisability of granting such
permission and may, if he deems it advisable, grant any such person permission
to tap in accordance with the prayer of this application, or may grant such
permission to tap under different conditions from those set forth in the
application if he deems it for the best. All such tapping shall be done under
the direction, and to the satisfaction of the City Engineer and Building
Official and in accordance with City of Portsmouth Storm Water Regulations on
file in the City Engineering Office, and wholly at the expense of the party
making such tap.
(Ord. 2001-76. Passed 7-23-01.)
923.02 TAPPING FEE.
   The fee for the tapping of any storm sewer within the City for any purpose
shall be two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00).
(Ord. 2016-169. Passed 12-12-16.)
923.03 DRAINAGE.
   Storm sewage, if not drained into a natural watercourse, shall be carried
under the sidewalk to the gutter, through a Schedule 40 PVC pipe so laid as to
be entirely below the grade of the walk, or through a cross-gutter having an
iron cover flush with the top surface of the walk, unless there is provided in
front of the premises a storm sewer, in which case the connection for sewage,
such as is provided shall be made into such storm sewer.
(Ord. 2016-154. Passed 11-14-16.)

925.01 COMPONENT PARTS OF THE SYSTEM.
   The sanitary sewer system of the City consists of main and lateral conduits
of salt-glazed vitrified earthenware. They are designed to carry off all house
waste and are known herein as sanitary sewers. The sewers in the streets
passing in front of the various lots are called main or lateral sewers. The
sewers leading from the main or lateral sewers to the property on either side
are called house connections.
925.02 PLUMBING AND SEWER BUILDING; LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall lay, alter or repair any house drain, sewer or plumbing
work, or make any connections whatever with any sewer or drain belonging to the
sanitary system, or do any kind of work connected with the laying of house
drains or house sewers or plumbing, or make any repairs, additions to or
alterations of any drain, sewer or plumbing connected with the sanitary sewer
system, unless regularly licensed by the City.
925.03 PLUMBING AND SEWER BUILDING; NOTICE AND PLANS.
   Every plumber and sewer builder, before doing any work connected with any
sewer, shall file with the Department of Engineering a notice and drawing of
the work to be performed, and no such work shall be done without the approval
of the Department of Engineering.
925.04 PLUMBERS AND SEWER BUILDERS; RESPONSIBILITY FOR WORK; BOND.
   Each plumber or sewer builder shall be held responsible for any injury he
may cause to any main or lateral sewer in the prosecution of his work, and
shall keep his work in repair for one year, and give bond in the sum of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for the faithful performance of his duties.
   The sewer builder must erect safeguards and maintain danger signals wherever
and whenever necessary. He will be liable for all damages to persons and
property caused by his acts of negligence.
   The sewer builder will also be held responsible for any subsequent
settlement of the ground and pavement, and must, upon notification, make the
same as good as before he began his work.
925.05 HOUSE CONNECTIONS; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   Permits shall be taken out in each special case for house connections in the
name of the owner, agent or person in whose interest the work is to be done,
before the work is commenced. In no case shall such work be prosecuted unless
such permit is on the ground, and in the possession of the person doing the
work.
925.06 PERMIT FEES IN THE CASE OF ASSESSED SEWERS.
   The appropriate permit fee, in accordance with Section
925.10, shall be paid to the City at the time the permit is issued, except that
those owners abutting and connecting to an assessed sewer within sixty days
after the completion thereof, may be issued a sewer tap permit without charge.
(Ord. 1963-25. Passed 3-14-63.)
925.07 CONTENTS OF PERMIT.
   Each permit required by Section
925.05 shall designate the street, the number of the house and lot and the size
of the house, and shall include such definite description as to clearly define
the location of the same.
925.08 SEPARATE PERMIT REQUIRED FOR EACH CONNECTION.
   No person shall connect with or tap a lateral pipe when permission to lay
such pipe has been granted to another. Each person desiring to use the sewer
must have a special permit for himself, whether he joins with another party in
making the connections with the sewer or not.
925.09 RECORDS OF DEPARTMENT OF ENGINEERING.
   The Department of Engineering shall keep a daily record of permits applied
for, allowed and rejected.
925.10 TAPPING CHARGES.
   The price to be charged for tapping the sanitary sewers of the City for
various purposes shall be determined and established as follows:
 
   (a)   For a building used only as a single family residence or dwelling unit $
100.00
   (b)   For a building containing several dwelling units,
      known as apartments, as follows:
      (1)   For the first apartment or dwelling unit      100.00
      (2)   For each additional apartment or dwelling
          unit therein                     20.00
   (c)   For a one-floor or two-floor building used only as
       one residence, or dwelling unit, and one
       business                     180.00
   (d)   For a building used only as a hotel or motel
       as follows:
      (1)   For hotels and motels occupying one floor
          therein                  200.00
      (2)   For each additional floor therein         100.00
      (3)   For each restaurant therein            200.00
   (e)   For a building used only as a boarding house      180.00
   (f)   For a building used only as a restaurant         200.00
   (g)   For a building used only as a factory         300.00
   (h)   For a building occupied by offices and
       businesses as follows:
         (1)   For the first floor occupied therein   $ 140.00
         (2)   For each additional floor therein   100.00
   (i)   For trailers, as follows:
         (1)   For first trailer in trailer court   100.00
         (2)   Plus for each additional trailer   20.00
   (j)   For schools, as follows:
         (1)   For a single floor school house   200.00
         (2)   For each additional floor   100.00
   (k)   For churches, regular fee      100.00
 
   (l)   For any building or property not included in the foregoing
classifications, Council may determine the fee to be paid upon application for
the permit.
   (m)   The fee must, in all cases, be paid when the permit is granted, and
the person, on securing the permit, shall pay all the expense of making the
connections, and keep the same in repair.
      (Ord. 1991-93. Passed 8-13-91.)
925.11 TRENCH BRACING.
   When the side of the trench will not stand vertical, sheathing braces shall
be used to prevent unnecessary caving.
925.12 PROXIMITY OF DRAIN PIPE TO WATER PIPE AT CROSSINGS; PROTECTION OF WATER
PIPES.
   The course of drain pipe shall be laid not nearer than eighteen inches to
any water pipe at crossings, and such water pipe shall be protected from
corrosion by a cement cover.
925.13 PROTECTION OF WATER AND GAS PIPES GENERALLY.
   All water pipes and gas pipes shall be protected from injury to the
satisfaction of the Department of Engineering.
925.14 LINE, DEPTH AND GRADE OF CONNECTIONS.
   All house connections shall be made straight, or in as direct a line as
possible, from the "Y" branches to the sewers into which the premises are
drained, and shall be at least four feet below the surface of the ground,
except where otherwise authorized by the City Engineer. All pipes shall be laid
to a proper grade of not less than one-quarter inch to every foot, where
practicable, by the use of the spirit level.
925.15 MATERIALS SPECIFICATIONS; PIPE AND JOINTS.
   Materials used in the construction of building sewers shall be first class,
free from defects, with a minimum diameter of five inches. The following
materials are approved by the Department of Engineering for building sewers.
   (a)   Salt-glazed vitrified clay pipe.
   (b)   Ceramic-glazed vitrified clay pipe.
   (c)   Cast-iron soil pipe.
   (d)   Unglazed vitrified clay tile.
   (e)   Type PSP (Poly Vinyl Chloride) PVC A.S.T.M. D-3033-74.
   (f)   Type PSM (Poly Vinyl Chloride) PVC A.S.T.M. D-3034-74.
   (g)   Type ABS (Acrylonitrile-Butadiene-Styrene) A.S.T.M. D-2751-73.
   (h)   Type ABX (Acrylonitrile-Butadiene-Styrene) A.S.T.M. D-2680-74.
   On vitrified clay pipe only, prefabricated joints, such as Ty-lox, Wedge-
lox, Am-Vit or their approved equal shall be used. No mortar joints or slip-
seal joints shall be allowed. Joints of cast-iron soil pipe shall be made with
oakum and lead.
   Curved pipe shall be used in all angles in the building sewer greater than
three inches deviation from a straight line in the length of one joint of pipe.
(Ord. 1978-33. Passed 3-28-78.)
925.16 CONNECTIONS WHERE NO "Y" HAS BEEN PLACED.
   Whenever it is necessary to make a connection with any main or lateral sewer
where no "Y" has been placed, the junction pipe shall be furnished by the sewer
builder, and the same shall be inserted under the supervision of the Department
of Engineering. Whenever it is necessary to cut into a sewer lateral or main,
the connection shall be made with the appropriate vitrified clay slant, flanged
"T" tap or flanged "Y" tap.
925.17 SUPERVISION OF CUTTING OR BREAKING INTO SEWERS.
   No sewer builder shall cut or break into a sewer unless the City Engineer or
his representative is upon the ground and gives approval of the method
employed.
925.18 CONNECTIONS OF LEAD WITH IRON PIPE.
   All connections of lead with iron pipe must be made with a brass sleeve or
ferrule of the same size as the lead pipe and thoroughly calked with lead, and
the lead pipe must be attached to the sleeve or ferrule by a wiped lead joint.
All connections of lead pipe must be wipe joints. Putty joints will not be
permitted.
925.19 EXTENSIONS OF SOIL, WASTE OR VENT PIPES.
   Soil, waste or vent pipes in an extension must be extended above the roof of
the main building when otherwise they would open within twenty feet of the
windows of the main house or the adjoining house. It must not open below a
window, nor an air shaft which ventilates living rooms, nor nearer than eight
feet to the same in any direction.
925.20 REMOVAL OF COVER OF "Y" BRANCH; ATTACHMENT OF FIRST LENGTH TO "Y"
BRANCH.
   The cover of the "Y" branch on the sewer shall be carefully removed so as
not to injure the socket. The first length attached to the "Y" branch shall be
curved and set so as to give a good fall into the sewer.
925.21 INSPECTION BY BOARD OF HEALTH.
   Pipes or other fixtures shall not be covered or concealed from view until
after the work has been examined by the Board of Health. Such Board shall be
notified when the work is sufficiently advanced for inspection.
925.22 UNINSPECTED PIPES; REMEDY BY BOARD OF HEALTH.
   Any house drain or sewer put in and covered without due notice to the Board
of Health or one of its assistants must be uncovered for inspection at the
discretion of the Board.
925.23 FAILURE TO COMPLY; REMEDY BY DEPARTMENT OF ENGINEERING.
   The Department of Engineering shall have the power to disconnect any or all
pipes to the sanitary sewer which are made before a permit has been obtained or
which are not made in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. The
Department of Engineering shall have like power to disconnect any and all taps
to the sanitary sewer through which substances or materials pass into the sewer
that are prohibited by the provisions of this chapter.
925.24 USE OF CESSPOOLS, VAULTS PROHIBITED WHERE SEWERS AVAILABLE.
   No sewer or kitchen drain for any building or premises shall discharge into
any cesspool, vault or other like receptacle, where such buildings or premises
abut on a street provided with proper sewerage accommodations with which the
same can be connected. If, at any future time, streets not having proper
sewerage accommodations are provided with same, then within sixty days after
such provision the further use of cesspools, vaults or other receptacles for
the disposal of sewage shall be discontinued and the proper connection be made
with the main or lateral sewer.
925.25 CONNECTION OF PRIVATE SEWERS; APPROVAL REQUIRED.
   Before any old or private drain or sewer is connected with the sewerage
system the owner of the private drain or sewer shall prove to the satisfaction
of the Department of Engineering that it is clean and conforms in every respect
with this chapter.
925.26 SEALING OF UNCONNECTED PRIVATE SEWERS.
   The ends of all private sewers not immediately connected with the plumbing
fixtures shall be securely closed by watertight imperishable material. If lead
pipe, the end must be soldered; if wrought iron pipe, a plug must be screwed
into the end; if cast-iron pipe, a cast-iron plug must be calked in with lead.
925.27 STRAINERS ON EXITS FROM PLUMBING FACILITIES.
   All exits from kitchen sinks, wash stands, slop hoppers, urinals and other
receptacles, except water closets and kitchen sinks equipped with garbage
disposal units, shall be provided with strong attached metal strainers, except
in the case of urinals and wash bowls already provided with good earthenware
strainers.
(Ord. 1963-25. Passed 3-14-63.)
925.28 OBSTRUCTION OF CONNECTIONS AND DRAINS.
   No trap or any manner of obstruction to the complete or perfectly free flow
of air throughout the entire course of the drain or house connections will be
permitted.
925.29 CONNECTION OF ROOF WATER, CISTERN OVERFLOW WITH SEWER.
   Roof water and overflow from cisterns or similar storage facilities shall
not be connected with the sewer unless otherwise authorized by the City
Engineer.
925.30 CONNECTION OF STEAM EXHAUST, BLOWOFF PIPE WITH SEWER.
   No steam exhaust or blowoff pipe from a steam boiler shall be connected with
any soil or waste pipe, or directly with the house drain. Instead, they shall
discharge into a tank or condenser, the waste from which, after being condensed
and suitably trapped, may enter the sewer.
925.31 CONNECTION OF SUBSOIL DRAINS FROM CELLARS WITH SEWER.
   Subsoil drains from cellars may be connected with the sewer, but the
connection must be made with the approval and under the supervision of the
Department of Engineering.
925.32 ACCESS TO FACILITIES; RESPONSIBILITY OF COMMISSIONER OF HEALTH.
   All sewers, drains, urinals, sewer gas and waste traps and pipe, and
everything pertaining to house drainage beyond the line of any street, lane,
alley or other public ground, shall be accessible to the Department of
Engineering, its employees and the Commissioner of Health, and shall, except
where otherwise provided, be under the care and control of the Commissioner of
Health.
925.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
901.99 if no penalty is otherwise provided.)
CHAPTER 927
Sanitary Sewerage Charges
